title: Does Bible Prophecy Point to the Modern State of Israel? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. The Israel that Bible prophecy points to is spiritual Israel. Natural Israel, as a nation, was cast off by God when they rejected Jesus as the Messiah. Matthew 23:37, 38 The Christian congregation of God took the place of the congregation of Israel at Pentecost of 33 C.E., when holy spirit was poured out on Jesus’ followers in Jerusalem. Inasmuch as the majority of the natural Israelites rejected Jesus Christ, “not all who spring from Israel are really ‘Israel,’” that is, spiritual Israel. (Ro 9:6-9) And, regarding the Christian congregation of God comprised of spiritual Jews, Paul stated: “He is not a Jew who is one on the outside, nor is circumcision that which is on the outside upon the flesh. But he is a Jew who is one on the inside, and his circumcision is that of the heart by spirit.”​—Ro 2:28, 29.

Short answer: Daniel 9 and 12 point to the existence of the temple and sacrifice at the end time, well after the fall of Jerusalem followed by the wars and desolations of history, Daniel 9:25–27. Daniel 12 takes up the abomination of desolation at the end time. Jesus referred to Daniel’s prophecies. So for the temple to exist we infer Israel would be restored. The early fathers of the church from the end of the 1st century through the 2nd century were are of a future fulfillment of this prophecy, especially Irenaeus.

Well. Imagine if state of Israel was never formed in 1948, then what would you say about this supposed prophecy? What will it “prophetise” in this case? Many people were aware of this supposed prophecy and were working intentionally to make it true. It is like in the restaurant: if I order a chicken and a water brings it to me, do I become a prophet?
Yes and No. Bible Prophesy points to America, Great Britain, AND Judah (or as most people know Judah, Israel. ) The United States and Britain in Prophecy

In no way, shape, or fashion. Israel has fulfilled it’s role in the Christ event. After the resurrection, they have become just like all other people - in need of Christ… From a Biblical perspective, that is.
